http://themysticpagan.com/

Why this book matters:

The Bible is a foundational book of our civilization.  Whether we be pagan, atheist, Hindi, Muslim, Buddhist, Jewish, Christian or something else, we are affected by the writings because the most basic of our western values have been shaped by its words.  The roots of our civilization have been built upon this foundation. 

But what if the lessons are different than what we think?  How would our lives be different?  How would our culture be different? 

It is only by changing the fundamental stories underpinning our culture that we can change the paradigms we live by. One Gods explores these fundamental stories and offers new paradigms based on the oldest of teachings.

One Gods is a deep dive of spiritual forensics, a journey through history using shamanic knowledge to explore cross-cultural teachings found in the Bible. Here are some examples of the connections:

  • Moses and the Celtic Bard Taliesin
  • Noah and the Hindu God Vishnu
  • The Shekinah, Venus and the MesoAmerican Quezalcóatl
  • Samson, Hercules and the Norse God Tyr 

The ancient mystery schools of Greece, Egypt and other cultures also hold many of the keys. 

One Gods also includes experiential exercises designed to deepen one's own spiritual fullness based on the Biblical lessons presented.  


A note on paganism:

While the word has become pejorative, “pagan” simply means countryside or peasant, someone who lives close to the land and in harmony with nature.  To those who stop to listen, each landscape has its own vibratory essence, its own music if you will.  It was (and still is) pagan peoples who have been nourished by this knowledge, and who have held it in sacred trust through oral, and later, written teachings. 


The Bible is a Document of Wonder and Mystery

The Bible is filled with wondrous happenings.  People speak directly to the Lord, or in other words, communicate with divinity. There are angels; an otherworldly serpent (discussed in Chapter 10), and a bush filled with fire that does not burn (discussed in Chapter 4).  Jerusalem is a focal point for the world's three major western patriarchal religions; yet the city retains the name of its original guiding deity who was not male.  Jerusalem was named for a goddess – Venus in her aspect as the evening star (discussed in Chapter 5)

Magic lurks within the mists of Biblical folklore; a stone that springs water (discussed in Chapter 3), a ladder ascending to the heavens (discussed in Chapter 6), a serpent perched upon a staff with the power to heal (discussed in Chapter 11). Teachings are veiled within the Hebrew language, its oldest script forged from the fires of the heavens (discussed in Chapter 8) Ancient knowledge lies hidden deep within the text. 

 The Bible contains great journeys between Canaan and Egypt and back again.  There are struggles, quests and heroes.  There is sacred wind/breath/speech giving rise to human life (discussed in Chapters 1 and 2), the Tower of Babel that confused human speech and still trips us up today when we try to understand what the writers felt and how they thought; symbols of power that still hold the keys to great mysteries.

There is the mystery of a God who can be both immanent and personal while at the same time being transcendent (discussed in Chapter 7). There is Adam or Adamah, whose name means red earth, and Eve or Chava, meaning life.  It could be said that it was Eve’s birthright to eat the fruit, for the Tree of Life bears her name, Chava, Life (discussed in Chapter 10).

In delving into these mysteries we don't strip away the wonderment but rather grow ever more amazed at how the nature of life, creation and mystery fit together in such perfection.  How did people know?  How could it be that knowledge in the Bible parallels knowledge held by MesoAmerican Aztecs (discussed in Chapter 2 and throughout the book)? Native Hawaiians (Chapter 1 and throughout the book)? The Celts of Britain or tribes of Tibet for that matter (Chapter 2 and throughout the book)? How can Biblical symbols contain such power so many thousands of years after they were first written?  How can they still capture our imaginations today? 

Exploring these wonders is a journey I have wanted to take my entire lifetime.  You are invited to join me in this adventure. 

My name is Janet Rudolph.  After a life long interest in comparative religion, I answered the call of shamanism almost 20 years ago.  I have traveled throughout the world to experience and learn first hand how the mysteries of life have come to be expressed, blessed, honored and lived in differing lands and cultures.  One Gods is the culmination of these experiences.  

Included in the book are some of the Biblical stories that I have rewritten with a shamanic outlook.  

The Video

Here is an excerpt of my story of Jacob as told in the video above (for those who like their stories in more static form).  The full story and discussion of this story appear in Chapter 6 of One Gods:

Jacob was a hero who had a vision of divinity.  He dreamt of a ladder, a staircase, some would call it a world tree.  He witnessed the unending interaction between the earthly and the divine.  He could clearly see their dance, how they joined, parted and joined again in unending movement.  He saw their essence - the secrets to their flowing energy.   That sacred dance which nurtures all words, seen and unseen.

At the place where he awoke from his dream of mysteries and angels, Jacob erected a stone pillar in the manner of the ancients.  It was a standing stone, a monument to the fertile earth with its gateway to other realms.  In doing so, he honored his ancestors, his vision and all creation.

Jacob had gone out into the world to find his family, his destiny and to learn of the mysteries.  Twenty years later he returned home.  Before entering his homeland, however, he went off by himself to go on a vision quest.  All through the night Jacob wrestled with the Great Mystery.


As the MorningStar rose in the sky, Jacob was initiated and like all new initiates, like his ancestors Abram and Sarai before him, he was granted a new name, a spirit name.  The name he was given was a blend of the gods of Egypt and Canaan.  He took the name of the moon goddess of the Egyptians (Isis) and the Egyptian sun god (Ra), along with the Great Bull God of the Canaanites (El).  Henceforth his name would be known as Is-Ra-El. 

(The photographs used in the video are my own. The tree was taken outside my doorway on the night of a full moon. The standing stones are from Brodgar, Scotland. The  "stream" photo is the Nile river. The photo "Dawn in Jerusalem" was taken when I visited the holy land as a teenager.  The photo of me on the front of the video was taken at Tintagel England in 1997.)


Notes on the Perks:
I print my own photographs on high quality photographic paper.   I use either Epson Ultra Premium Photo Paper Luster with K2 inks or Canon Pro Luster paper with Pixma inks.   Other papers of equal quality may be substituted based on availability and needs of specific prints.  The prints will arrive ready for matting and framing.   I hoping to have the books earlier than the stated fulfillment dates.   The manuscript is finished and the planned lead time is to insure time to obtain the legal permissions to use images and quotes and well as the designing of the finished product.  

Funding Needs:

I have traveled to many lands seeking wisdom and guidance from spiritual teachers, spent years (or it is a lifetime?) researching cultures and gathering photographs.  Along the way I have danced upon beaches, climbed pyramids, experienced initiations, walked in the processional pathways of the ancients, felt standing stones against my skin, entered spirals and labyrinths, and hugged the earth in its oneness and yet many sacred facets - from the deserts of Egypt, to the lush rainforests of the Mayans, to  windswept castles of southern France, to wildly rushing mountain streams in the Pacific Northwest. 

I am now asking for help in completing the process and bringing the dream of this book to fruition.  To keep it simple I have kept my request to a minimum.  I am asking for the help for further professional editing, layout and design services, permissions fees, and printing charges (at VirtualBookworm).  I have also included in the figuring fees to Indiegogo, paypal, taxes and costs associated with fulfilling perks.  If I exceed my goal, I will use the additional funding to mount a marketing campaign and begin the process of translating One Gods into Spanish. 

For more information and excerpts from ONE GODS check out my website:  http://themysticpagan.com/

story:
Short Summary

Book Fight! is a weekly literature and writing podcast hosted by Mike Ingram and Tom McAllister, both of whom are writers, college professors, and editors at Barrelhouse magazine. Every Monday since April 2012, we've posted a new ~60-90 minute episode for free.  All 100+ episodes in the archive have remained free to download.

In a review of the show, The AV Club wrote:

"Overall, Book Fight! tends to be an enjoyable chat with two dudes who get passionate about the craft, call out authors on their bullshit, shout-out great lit when they read it, and consume a lot of pop culture. Book club with these guys isn’t the tedious chore it can be when sitting around the living room of someone you don’t even like, drinking bad wine. Sometimes they fight. "

We love doing the show and have a ton of fun doing it, but it is a lot of work and there are ongoing expenses. We're asking regular listeners (and new listeners who want to support independent voices in literature) to donate to the show so that we can keep it going, continue improving it, and keep it free to download each week. 

We hope you'll consider your donation a small subscription fee for the 60+ hours of free entertainment we upload every week. Your donations will help us to finance equipment upgrades, cover ongoing administrative costs, and (we hope) pay for more live shows on the road. 


What We Need & What You Get

This year, we're trying to raise $5,000. Any progress toward this ultimate goal will help us to achieve a number of incremental goals:

  • Paying ongoing administrative costs: web hosting on Wordpress and file hosting on Libsyn, plus the cost of new books (only one book in the show's history has been sent as a review copy, and while we like throwing our money at authors and publishers--especially independent publishers--this is an out-of-pocket cost that does add up).
  • Equipment upgrades: we'd love to get a fourth microphone so we can accommodate an extra guest from time to time, and also higher quality mics to improve sound quality on the show. We'd also like to get equipment to improve our mobile recording capabilities so that we can accommodate guests who can't make it to New Jersey to record. This would widen our range of possible guests and allow us to bring more new and exciting voices to the show.
  • Live shows on the road! We love the community that has sprung up around this show and we'd really like to bring the show out to our fans. This past year, we hosted our first live show here in Philadelphia, and we'd love to do live shows in other cities--including yours. But touring costs a lot of money, and we are far from rich! Note that this is probably the biggest expense on this list.
  • Any cash left over will be treated as a (small) salary for our work on the show, which is posted free and receives no ad revenue of any kind. 
  • There are lots of fun perks for donors! 
  • If we reach our goal of $5000, we'll record another bonus episode based on a book chosen by our listeners. Last year, you voted for us to discuss Silver Linings Playbook, in an episode that turned out to be a fan favorite. What will it be this year? 
  • Because Book Fight is an offshoot of Barrelhouse, a registered 501 (c)(3) non-profit literary publisher, your donation is 100% tax deductible. 

The Impact

We've been doing this show for a while now, and we think our track record speaks for itself. We've done several fund raisers, and each time we've come through for you with a better show and great giveaways. 

Look, we don't want to overstate our importance, but there's a great value to having independent literary voices in the world. We review all kinds of books, from canonical texts to works in translation to graphic novels to small press story collections, and we do it without being beholden to any corporate interests, so you know you're getting a no-bullshit take on the literary world. Agree or disagree with our opinions, you know you can trust our show to be a unique, honest voice in a lit world that is sometimes so concerned with politeness that it's hard to tell what's hype and what's real. 

Risks & Challenges

We've got a track record here. For nearly 3 years, we've produced weekly episodes, plus occasional bonus episodes. You can count on us to keep working hard to produce a high-quality show for you. Your donation is your vote of confidence in what we're doing, and it's one we take to heart. You can trust that the money you contribute will go to good use in sustaining this show. 

The greatest challenge we might face is in figuring out the logistics of planning and organizing live shows on the road. These events require lots of coordination with local venues, guests, and media. It's possible that we could try to organize a road trip and it will be a disaster. But we have experience in this area, too, thanks to the many events we've organized as part of Barrelhouse, and we have a large network of friends in the lit community, so we're confident we can count on these resources to help us make the best use of your contributions. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, we hope you'll help us spread the word, using Indiegogo's share tools and telling your friends on social media. 

You can also support the show by rating us in iTunes, Stitcher, or whatever service you use for downloading and listening to podcasts. And explaining to your literature-loving friends a) what a podcast is, and b) why they should start listening to this one.

Thanks for your ongoing support of the show!

story:
The Institute for Cultural Evolution think tank is raising funds for a public opinion campaign to help free America from the paralysis of political polarization

The Institute for Cultural Evolution (“ICE”) is focusing on the problem of political polarization in America, and we have a plan to help depolarize the American electorate through cultural evolution.

Here’s the problem: political gridlock in Washington is preventing meaningful action on pressing issues we care deeply about. Issues such as climate change, the vanishing middle class, Federal deficits, outdated tax policy, and many others.

While many have lost hope, concluding that our government is controlled by moneyed interests with no progress possible, we’re not ready to give up on America’s democracy. But we do recognize how polarization is exacerbated by the fact that most political issues have now become identity issues wherein the merits of policy are trumped by “tribal” loyalties.

Notwithstanding these challenges, we have a realistic solution that involves fostering political evolution for both the near term, and for the 2016 election and beyond. ICE is now engaged in a campaign to evolve American public opinion on both the Left and the Right by bringing forward a vision of more evolved versions of both sides of the spectrum, and we're asking for your help.

What we want to do

The money we raise on Indiegogo will help us organize, promote, and sustain our efforts to Depolarize the American mind. Our strategy starts with the recognition that the liberal/conservative polarity is an indelible feature of our body politic, which continues to reappear in new form as society evolves. So we are fostering further evolution by advancing a vision of the “Future Right” and the “Future Left.” These more evolved political positions will better integrate the wisdom of their opponents, while continuing to stand for the core values that animate each side. By showing how each side actually needs the other for its own mature expression, we can help create a political climate in America where new agreements will become possible.

Our website features a detailed whitepaper and video presentation on our strategy, as well as a polarization test that shows how you can become part of the solution. We’re also co-creating conferences and events, such as the recent Conclave on Polarization at the Esalen Center for Theory and Research in California. (Below is an image of our polarization test, click on this link to go to the live test.)

Beyond this, we’re also inviting you to participate in a series of free virtual caucus calls, which  help define and develop these Future Left and Future Right positions. These teleconference caucus calls, hosted by ICE’s principals, feature panels of thought leaders who discuss the issues and explore ways to evolve thinking on both the Left and Right. The caucus calls also provide a forum for a large audience of call participants who can voice their opinions and help create more effective expressions of both progressive and conservative political positions.                 (Please click on this link to go to our Caucus Call webpage)

The first caucus for the "Future of the Left" was held on October 25th, and an audio recording is available on the ICE website. The inaugural caucus for the "Future of the Right" will be held in early December.

What will funds be used for?

Our initial funding goal is $25,000. We estimate this amount will pay for:

• Publicity and public relations ($15,000)

• Principal and staff time ($8,000)

• Website development, teleconference engineer, and technical support ($2,000)

All contributions are tax deductible

What is the Institute for Cultural Evolution?

ICE is a Colorado-based 501c3 nonproﬁt  think tank that focuses on the cultural roots of America’s challenges. We are a group of “evolutionary” authors and activists who are working to evolve America’s political conversation. Through groundbreaking research, high-level conferences, and grass roots activism, we are helping create  forward movement in our national political landscape. ICE’s current focus is political polarization as described in our acclaimed white paper: Depolarizing the American Mind: How America Can Grow Beyond Its Currently Polarized Politics

ICE works and partners with other great organizations to achieve our goals, including Esalen Institute’s Center for Theory and Research, Conscious Capitalism, and others. Our Officers and Board of Directors can be seen here.

What’s in it for you?

Your contribution will help us influence American politics by making this appealing vision of political progress visible in the marketplace of ideas. This is an opportunity to help put “evolutionary/integral politics” on the cultural map. By funding our caucus call project and supporting our larger political polarization campaign you will become “part of the solution.” All contributors will be personally thanked on our website (unless you ask us not to), and contributors will also receive the perks listed on the right.

How else can you participate?

Beyond contributing to our crowdfunding campaign, we invite you to participate in one or more of our planned caucus calls. We also invite you to take our on-line “polarization test” and read our campaign whitepaper: Depolarizing the American Mind. Further, we invite you to leave a comment on our website or facebook page, and otherwise spread the word …

story:
Common Courtesy and Good Manners


You Sir, Are A Gentleman is an effort to make the world a better and more pleasant place to live by spreading common courtesy and good manners.

Many people are concerned by the "rudification" of society and the fact that people have become more individualistic. Common courtesy and good manners are sometimes seen as lost arts. 

Gentlemen can be key in reversing the "rudification of society" process. Gentlemen by definition practice common courtesy and good manners. They treat people with respect, influence people in a positive way and can make good manners and common courtesy a little bit more.. common.

You Sir Are A Gentleman want's to teach people how to be a gentleman in order to create more gentlemen. 


You Sir, Are A Gentleman

The book focuses on the behavior, the actions, the mindset and the appearance of a modern gentleman. A modern gentleman's appearance is not the most import thing in the book, but it is a vital part because not stinking up a room with dirty clothes and a scruffy beard is also a form of common courtesy. 

"A gentleman is one who puts more into the world than he takes out." George Bernard Shaw

The most important thing is that being a gentleman is something you do everyday. Practicing common courtesy and good manners and treat other people with respect on a daily basis will be the key message of You Sir, Are A Gentleman. This will make the world a better and more pleasant place to live.

Funds

The funds generated with the Kickstarter project will be spend on an editor, a proofreader and an illustrator to make You Sir, Are A Gentleman a high quality product. Residual funds (if any) will be spend on advertisement. 

Music - "Good to Go" by Josh Woodward.Icons made by Freepik, Appzgear, SimpleIcon from flaticon.com

story:
Tandem Reader Awards is a FEE-FREE post-publication award for chapbooks, where the award will be given to both the author and editor of the winning chapbook. TRA began as an idea in 2015 when we noticed a deficit of reader awards for chapbooks and a similar deficit of reader awards for editors. As we discussed these needs in our community, we realized an additional and more prevalent need in our community for more accessible awards.

We believe it is important to acknowledge the hurdles, including submission fees, impeding accessibility to many awards in our creative community, especially for minority and marginalized voices. We asked ourselves: What if we could award the special relationship between writer and editor, while pledging our commitment to being broadly accessible within the literary community by maintaining fee-free nominations? The answer was clear: We can. These ideas work beautifully in tandem and you can help make it happen.

Our goal is to raise a minimum of $2,000 to cover the initial start-up costs: A PO box for mail nominations, a checking account, promotional materials, and registering for our 501c3. Additionally your contribution will go towards the $150 prize awarded each to the editor and the author of the winning chapbook, and will guarantee the first two years of the awards. Any additional funds raised over $2,000 will sweeten the prize pot; we hope to surpass the $150 prize amount for our winners and demonstrate community support and commitment to a more inclusive writer community, where we can honor the work first and foremost.

We know it’s not easy to get off the ground and that not-for-profits can be tricky, but our team of volunteers knows that a more accessible award is a necessity for our community, and that we broaden ourselves and our greater community by giving those marginalized voices a chance to be heard and celebrated for their works. By celebrating the partnership between editor and writer, and the beauty that is small batch printings, we hope to foster an increase in these beautiful works of mutual art. Sundress Publications feels the same way, too, and has agreed to sponsor Tandem Reader Awards under their 501c3 until we have reached our funding goal, which means that your donation is TAX DEDUCTIBLE and supported by an experienced nonprofit.

To help further support writers, SAFTA will house the top 10 chapbooks from each reading period at their residency at Firefly Farms in Knoxville, TN, to be permanently housed in their libraryfor future residents to enjoy. In the event that our fundraiser is unable to make sufficient operating costs, funds collected will be used to fund a scholarship for the Firefly Farms residency for marginalized voices.

Donating to our campaign also has some really nice—and unique—perks! More details on specific perks can be found at tandemreaderawards.com/2016-fundraiser.

Perks:
  • $1 Thank You!

Any and all contributions are welcome and one dollar goes a long way to reaching our goal. Thank you for your support!

  • $5 Digital Shout Out

  We will publicly recognize your support through social media so that the world   knows not only do you support Tandem Reader Awards, but a more inclusive and   supportive literary community across the globe. Thank you!

  • $10 Sentimental Asylum Hand-Printed Card. 
Choose from: “Rocket Ship,” “This Sucks Octopus,” “Diver Down,” and “Loch Ness Monster 'believe in yourself'.”
  • $15 Handwritten poems 
Signed by the author (Buy more than one, pay no additional shipping). Choose from: Kaveh Akbar, Heather Bell, Sarah Blake, Chen Chen, Siaara Freeman, and Megan Peak.
  • $20 Rattle Subscription for One Year

Receive a one-year subscription to the poetry magazine, Rattle! (max 10)

  • $25 Meggie Royer Postcard Sets

 Receive a limited edition Meggie Royer postcard set signed by Meggie Royer

  • $25 Sundress Book Bundle

Get two single author books of your choice from Sundress Publications.

  • $25 Early Bird Mail Nomination

With your donation, you are able to nominate 1 chapbook early. Donor will be provided a mailing address to one of our readers. Women writers will be able to also send a PDF to our email to have considered for the Sundress Wardrobe. Chapbook will be shared on our social media (FB, Twitter) and updated on our website.

  • $40 Maverick Duck Press Book Bundle

Receive brand new copies of 5 chapbooks by Maverick Duck Press: Mile Zero by Ryan W. Bradley, Cautionary Tales by Raina Masters, Monarch by Taylor Emily Copeland, Bone Transmissions by Christian Ward, and How to Disappear by Kendall A. Bell, donated by Maverick Duck Press.

  • $40 Custom Broadside of Your Own Work

A digital broadside crafted by Orooj-e-Zafar. Up to 30 lines of poetry or equivalent of prose.

  • $40 Francesca Bell Broadsides

Receive two broadsides of the Francesca Bell poems "Scorpion" and "As If God" printed on 5 x 7 heavy stock. Featuring art by Jeremy Gaulke.
  • $45: SAFTA Workshop Gift Card

Receive a $50 gift card good towards any SAFTA workshop or retreat

  • $45: Early Bird Mail Bulk Nomination

With your donation, you are able to nominate 2-5 chapbooks early. Donor   will be provided a mailing address to one of our readers. Women writers   will be able to also send a PDF to our email to have considered for the   Sundress Wardrobe. Chapbook will be shared on our social media (FB, Twitter) and updated on our website.

  • $50: Alice James Book Bundle

Receive brand new copies of three Spring 2016 titles:  play dead by francine j. harris, The Big Book of Exit Strategies by Jamaal May, and Driving Without a License by Janine Joseph, donated by Alice James Books.

  • $50: Chapbook Bundle

Receive 5 chapbooks from this years submissions, to be mailed after our judging period.

  • $70: Copper Canyon Book Bundle 

Receive four brand new copies of four first-book authors: When My Brother Was an Aztec by Natalie Diaz, Bangalore by Kerry James Evans, Incorrect Merciful Impulses by Camille Rankine, and Night Sky with Exit Wounds by Ocean Vuong, donated by Copper Canyon Press.

  • $75: Custom Drink Recipe by Sam Slaughter

  Have your very own signature drink recipe created by Spirits Writer Sam   Slaughter!

  • $80: BOA Book Bundle

Receive brand new copies of four BOA award winners AND a limited edition copy of Li-Young Lee's new chapbook:  Shame|Shame by Devin Becker, Reptile House by Robin McLean, Trouble the Water by Derrick Austin, Remarkable by Dinah Cox, and The Word From His Song by Li-Young Lee, donated by BOA Editions.

  • $80: Milkweed Book Bundle **SOLD OUT**

Receive brand new copies of: Vessel by Parneshia Jones, Beautiful Zero by Jennifer Willoughby, Double Jinx by Nancy Reddy, Bone Map by Sara Eliza Johnson, and Dandarians by Lee Ann Roripaugh, donated by Milkweed Editions.

  • $250:  Naming Rights to the President's New(ish) Ride

Rhiannon has just purchased a 2005 Mitsubishi Eclipse for upcoming graduate school at LSU. Name her ride (nothing offensive) to be proudly displayed on a bumper sticker. Receive your certificate of naming rights by mail.


Unable to support Tandem Reader Awards with a financial donation? Help us spread the word about our fundraiser and upcoming fee-free awards by sharing our campaign on social media. Use the Indiegogo share tools and our hashtag, #TRA. You can find us on Facebook and Twitter: @TandemAwards. Give us a follow and invite your friends to follow us, too! Share our posts and re-tweet our tweets! Thanks for your help!

story:
Short Summary

Nepantla is a new poetry e-journal, dedicated to Queer Poets of Color, being curated by Christopher Soto in collaboration with The Lambda Literary Foundation. The mission of Nepantla is to nurture, celebrate, and preserve diversity within the queer poetry community. The journal will be a groundbreaking collection of some the best poetry from the QPOC community.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Funds which are raised for Nepantla will be used to pay (60) contributors a $25 honorarium. Funds will also be used to cover the costs of Nepantla's editorial, technical, and design support team.

 

The Impact

This year alone, Nepantla will be releasing its first annual poetry e-journal, facilitating poetry workshops for queer youth of color, and hosting a QPOC poetry reading series. In the years to come, Nepantla would like to expand even further and stabilize itself as a central resource for the QPOC poetry community. Come be a part of the movement!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Post our Indiegogo to your social media sites!
  • Visit The Lambda Literary Foundation to read our submission guidelines and submit your poems!

story:
The introductory pamphlet guides you through the process of understanding why gratitude is so important to our overall health & happiness and helps open your eyes to just how much you have to be grateful for!

Who will you write your Greatest Gift(s) for? Some ideas:

  • Your co-worker
  • Your brother or sister
  • Your Mom or Dad
  • Your best friend!
  • Your significant other
  • Your son or daughter
  • A mentor

 

The journal itself begins by allowing you to tell the recipient why you’re giving them this beautiful gift. Doing this sets the tone for the rest of the journal.

 

You then have up to 21 pages to write as much (or as little) as you'd like. You can choose exactly how many pages you'd like to write and design, up to 21.

You can use the right side to write about a specific story, moment, quality or characteristic that you're grateful for about the special person.

You can use the left side as to include pictures, doodles, quotes, or other visuals to bring your story to life.

Your Storytelling Pack makes this so EASY!

Not a good writer, storyteller, or designer?

We've got you covered.

 

Writing Prompts & Guidance

The 30-inspirational writing prompts that are included make writing the journal and filling it with the reasons you’re grateful for the recipient simple & easy to do.

You don’t need to do any thinking. If you read the prompts, the writing inspiration will come to you without effort.

They’re specifically based on the research behind the qualities of valuable relationships, and lead you through re-experiencing and expressing why your relationship with the recipient is so special.

Designing Materials

We also specifically included 400+ different pieces of designing materials to fill the journal with visual representations of your relationship.

The value of these tools is that ANYONE, regardless of creative talent, can seamlessly make the gift look like a creative masterpiece.

Consist of:

- 60+  Premium stickers with specific phrases to accent your story 

- 200+ Givemoji stickers

- 6 Border frames

- 20 Photo-holders

- An adhesive envelope to put cherished items in

- Text Prompt Stickers & 6 Sticker Lists

All of this allows you to easily fill every page!

 

  • Textured, soft to the touch, highly durable synthetic-leather build
  • The journal lays flat while open
  • It measures in at 9.25" by 7.5"
  • Inside pages are thick and minimize bleeding

 

Make a presentation they'll remember forever.

When you're done filling out your Greatest Gift journal and are ready to gift it, there's no need to go to a store to buy a card, a bag, or wrapping supplies.

The included Gifting Pack comes with high-quality wrapping paper, a greeting card, and an envelope.

  • "Keep on spreading the love" premium gold foil stamping
  • Matte red paper on the inside
  • Soft, matte lamination finish that's soft to the touch
  • Beautiful bow design on the outside
  • Built with high quality materials only to last a lifetime

 

Of course with a gift like this, you can take your time to fill out each entry and make it as meaningful as possible.

Story of My Book

The Marching Women is a book that explores the intersections of women and public policy. It provides insights from inspiring young women and a framework for how to get involved in politics to create positive change in our communities.

My name is Marisa Lemma and I am the author of The Marching Women. I wrote this book because I feel as though the voices of women — young women in particular — are not being heard or taken seriously in the political arena. More young women need to not just get involved in politics, but also realize that by doing this, they can have a positive impact on their communities.

The Marching Women is a non-fiction book that speaks to all generations of women, and explores the ways to get our newer generations actively involved in politics so that the future is in good hands.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover how important young women are in public policy and how much of an impact they can actually have. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for public policy in you. Ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you use your voice to create positive change in your own communities.

In this book, you'll learn about inspiring young women who have made a difference in their communities and the ways in which you, too, can make a difference. For example, you'll read stories about:
  • Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the youngest member of the House of Representatives, who used social media to overthrow the incumbent in her district
  • Pooja Tanjore, the Virginia State Director of Rise to Run, whose main goal is to get more young women involved in politics
  • Greta Thunberg, the young Swedish activist who has forced climate change to become a worldwide policy priority
You don’t have to be a young woman interested in politics to love this book. If you are passionate about empowering women or you have ever felt like your voice isn’t being heard by our politicians, this is the book for you.
 

The Book - The Marching Women

The book is written in 2 Parts.

Part 1 contains the introduction and Chapters 1-3. It includes, among other things, a brief history of women in public service and a look at what young women in particular can bring to politics.

Part 2 contains Chapters 4-8. This section of the book is the more practical section. It provides a framework for how to get involved in politics, drawing on the experiences of those who have successfully done so. There is a chapter about starting locally, with insights from people such as Lucy Greenman and Pooja Tanjore. Another chapter focuses on the use of social media as an effective policy tool, and provides stories from people like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Emma Gonzalez.
 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in July 2020
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this summer
When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your name will appear in a special Acknowledgements section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

About the Author

Marisa Lemma is a second semester senior at the College of William & Mary. She is a government major and economics minor, and will be pursuing a Master of Public Policy at the University of Virginia next year.

Marisa wrote this book because she is very passionate about empowering women, and believes that young women play a particularly important role in crafting policies that would benefit the younger generations. She believes that now, more than ever, women need to step up and make their voices heard in the political arena.

Aside from writing, Marisa loves playing music and learning foreign languages. She has been playing the flute for 11 years, and is an active member of the William & Mary Pep Band. She is a Teaching Assistant for the Italian department at her school, and this year she also began learning French.

For more information, you can contact Marisa via email at marisa.lemma7@gmail.com, or connect with her on LinkedIn at https://www.linkedin.com/in/marisalemma/.
 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
  • Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #TheMarchingWomen and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page
  • Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or direct message on social media, if possible.
Thank you so much of all of your love and support! I would not be able to do this without you.

Thanks again,
Marisa Lemma

story:
Lit Youngstown: We're About All Things Writing in Youngstown

Help lift a new literary arts organization off the ground! Youngstown, Ohio, is a small rust belt city with a big heart. Your help will foster a project to give Youngstown a greater voice.

Why the Literary Arts?

The literary arts, music and the visual arts generate economic activity in our region, and help make Youngstown a great place to live. The acts of writing and reading foster creativity, an increased understanding of self, a strengthening of community, and a broader knowledge of the world.

Our programs and events focus on many aspects of the literary arts: honing craft; publishing; performing; and engaging with literature. We offer workshops led by skilled writers each spring, summer and fall, for writers and readers of all ages and experience levels.

We host a monthly first Wednesday prose and poetry reading at Suzie’s Dogs & Drafts in downtown Youngstown. Our featured readers are a wonderful mix of local and regional writers. The open mic that follows gives other writers an opportunity to share their work.

Our Vision

Through our classes and First Wednesday readings we have connected with hundreds of Youngstowners interested in literary arts. We’re asking for your support so we can continue to reach out to a wider population in the area and to attract teachers and visiting writers who can connect with them.

At the YSU Summer Festival of the Arts, more than 1000 people received a reusable tote bag (sponsored by the Green Team and Green Youngstown) imprinted with the winning poem in our ekphrastic poetry contest. We want to make more writing  that visible to the public, and invite more of Youngstown's diverse and talented writers to participate in our programs.

We are incorporated as a State of Ohio and federal nonprofit with 501 (c) (3) status.

Our Goals

We are frankly overflowing with ideas for programs and classes, but our immediate need is for $2500 for some specific goals:

·  Funding for workshops (scholarships, teacher stipends, rental costs): $500

·  Funding for community outreach writing projects: $500

·  Promotional materials like business cards and flyers: $500

·  Honorariums for visiting writers: $500

·  Writing Made Visible: pairing writers and visual artists in collaborative projects: $500

Risks & Challenges

Our area is rich with talent and interest in the literary arts. We've connected with dozens of writers through our classes and readings; but we want to continue to reach out to those with stories aching to be told who are not able to connect through traditional channels. 

We have strong ties to writers, teachers, and community agencies who will help us to build these connections. For example, our partnership with YSU's Summer Festival of the Arts; the YWCA of Youngstown's story telling fundraiser; and Youngstown Neighborhood Development Corporation for our work at a Better Block event. Your funding will help us to build these programs and make them stronger.

Keep In Touch

You can find us on our blog, LitYoungstown.wordpress.com or on our Facebook page. To receive our monthly newsletter, please contact us at LitYoungstown@gmail.com.

Whether or not you can contribute, please help us spread the word by sharing our campaign with others.

story:
I'm Cristina Deptula, publisher of Synchronized Chaos Magazine and publicist with Authors, Large and Small. A colleague and writer friend of nearly ten years who lives in Alexandria, Egypt, would like to publish a short story collection through a small independent press. Jaylan Salah has a medical background and was trained as a pharmacist, which in her country is more like a physician's assistant, in terms of education and ability to diagnose and select treatments. She chose that path to provide medical services in the poor rural areas of Egypt where the people can't afford full physicians. 

Jaylan also writes on behalf of women's and minority rights, when it's still dangerous to do that with the unsettled political situation. And she's got a short story collection she hopes to bring out soon, about the challenges and difficulties people face, and the ways they find to live normal human lives, within human bodies, despite political repression and uncertainty. Book will come out in Arabic first, then English and other languages soon, and will be professionally edited. 

Link to some of Jaylan's poetry, published in Synchronized Chaos Magazine: http://synchchaos.com/?p=7808

Link to Jaylan's author page on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/jaylanpoeticmuses


She's located a reputable Egyptian small press that will publish her work, for a payment of $500 US dollars, which we are in the process of helping her raise within the next month or two. (The extra cash is to cover Indiegogo and PayPal fees and any extra costs we might incur, such as payment for our staff's time working on this fundraiser.)

Would appreciate it if you'd consider making a donation of some amount and/or spreading the word to your contacts! She has cousins in New Jersey who accept checks and send the money safely to her in Egypt.

Short Summary

  • Chelsea Clemmons is an author with a degree in English and a creative writing minor who has been published in Noir Nation No. 3 and Flash Fiction Magazine. 
  • I've read HUNDREDS of romance novels in my time. I always thought it would be awesome if I could order a customized one for my own private enjoyment, so I decided to make this a possibility for readers all over the world.
  • For whatever contribution you can make, you get your own 100% custom personal, private romance novel to enjoy!


What We Need & What You Get


  • I'm going to need at least $500 to cover design costs and printing costs. 
  • We have perk packages! Be sure to check them out.
  • This campaign has flexible funding, which means that any funds contributed will be kept.


    Risks & Challenges


    • There is a chance that I won't reach goal, but I'm not going to let that stop me from providing my contributors with their customized novels.
    • If I get a massive influx of orders, it may take me a while to get to writing your novel. Never fear! I will keep you regularly updated, and will email you each chapter as I write it.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Short Summary

Writopia Lab is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that runs creative writing workshops for young writers ages 8 to 18 in our 11 locations across three states. In these workshops Writopia Lab focuses on fostering joy, literacy, and critical thinking in children and teens from all backgrounds through creative writing.

After working as a Scholastic Awards Outreach Partner for two years in New York City, Writopia Lab was invited in 2012 by the Alliance for Young Artists & Writers (the organization that runs the Awards) to administer the Hudson-to-Housatonic Writing Region. The H2H Writing Region serves young writers in nine counties north of New York City: Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange, Ulster, and Dutchess counties in New York; Fairfield, Litchfield, and New Haven counties in Connecticut.

Any student in grades 7 to 12 can submit to the Scholastic Art & Writing Awards. Every year, hundreds of works by Writopia Labs students are awarded regional and national recognition by the Scholastic Art & Writing Awards, the most of any single school or program nationwide.The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards provide budding writers and artists with numerous opportunities for recognition, scholarships, and a sense of community on both a regional and a national level.

Any contributions would be greatly appreciated. Fundraising will be used to provide more scholarship opportunities for our incredible writers.


What We Need & What You Get

Currently, the Hudson-to-Housatonic region of the Scholastic Awards can offer one $1000 scholarship-- The Madeleine L’Engle Award-- for a stunning senior portfolio, but we’re looking for more!

We are planning to offer 3 scholarships for 3 more wonderful seniors!

  • The Exquisite Essay Award -- $300 -- Highest Scored in Essay/Memoir (Journalism, Personal Essay/Memoir, Persuasive Writing)
  • The First-Rate Fiction Award -- $300 -- Highest Scored in Fiction (Flash Fiction, Science Fiction/Fantasy, Short Stories)
  • The Passionate Poetry Award -- $300 -- Highest Scored in Poetry

& What You Get:

Anyone who donates $20 or more gets his or her name incorporated into a fantastic short-story!

Anyone who donates $100 or more gets his or her name mentioned in the program of the Scholastic Regional Awards.




Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to donate, please spread the word about Writopia, Scholastic, and our fundraiser! Writopia Lab is committed to creating and sustaining a diverse community of young writers, and your support will play a vital role in helping us to further encourage young writers across the region.

Short SummaryWritopia Lab is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that runs creative writing workshops for young writers ages 8 to 18 in our 11 locations across three states. In these workshops Writopia Lab focuses on fostering joy, literacy, and critical thinking in children and teens from all backgrounds through creative writing.After working as a Scholastic Awards Outreach Partner for two years in New York City, Writopia Lab was invited in 2012 by the Alliance for Young Artists & Writers (the organization that runs the Awards) to administer the Hudson-to-Housatonic Writing Region. The H2H Writing Region serves young writers in nine counties north of New York City: Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange, Ulster, and Dutchess counties in New York; Fairfield, Litchfield, and New Haven counties in Connecticut.Any student in grades 7 to 12 can submit to the Scholastic Art & Writing Awards. Every year, hundreds of works by Writopia Labs students are awarded regional and national recognition by the Scholastic Art & Writing Awards, the most of any single school or program nationwide.The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards provide budding writers and artists with numerous opportunities for recognition, scholarships, and a sense of community on both a regional and a national level.Any contributions would be greatly appreciated. Fundraising will be used to provide more scholarship opportunities for our incredible writers.What We Need & What You GetCurrently, the Hudson-to-Housatonic region of the Scholastic Awards can offer one $1000 scholarship-- The Madeleine L’Engle Award-- for a stunning senior portfolio, but we’re looking for more!We are planning to offer 3 scholarships for 3 more wonderful seniors!

The Exquisite Essay Award -- $300 -- Highest Scored in Essay/Memoir (Journalism, Personal Essay/Memoir, Persuasive Writing)


The First-Rate Fiction Award -- $300 -- Highest Scored in Fiction (Flash Fiction, Science Fiction/Fantasy, Short Stories)


The Passionate Poetry Award -- $300 -- Highest Scored in Poetry

& What You Get: Anyone who donates $20 or more gets his or her name incorporated into a fantastic short-story! Anyone who donates $100 or more gets his or her name mentioned in the program of the Scholastic Regional Awards.Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you are unable to donate, please spread the word about Writopia, Scholastic, and our fundraiser! Writopia Lab is committed to creating and sustaining a diverse community of young writers, and your support will play a vital role in helping us to further encourage young writers across the region.

story:
Story of My Book

The Changemaker Attitude: Why individuals matter in the fight against climate change. A book about eco innovators around the world. 

My name is Jordan Fox and I am the author of The Changemaker Attitude. I wrote this book to inspire a more optimistic outlook on climate change and encourage people to take action and confront this overwhelming issue.

*For the first 100 physical books preordered, all proceeds will go to Protect Our Winters. (POW helps passionate outdoor people protect the places and lifestyles they love from climate change.)*

The Changemaker Attitude is a non-fiction book that speaks to the younger generation and those scared about the future and are looking for a new mindset to tackle climate change.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover how to use positivity to address climate change. I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for the world in you. Ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you avoid the paralyzing fear traps that plague people all over the world and begin to take action!

In this book, you'll learn about young eco innovators who are changing the world:

  • Alhaji Bah who created a company that creates handcrafted paper bags and briquettes made from coconut shells with his last $20
  • Anirudh Sharma whose company turns pollution into ink 
  • Angel Wu a student who is currently trying to turn organic waste materials from the city of Philadelphia into packaging material
You will love this book if you want to hear about the inspiring steps being taken by people just like you to create a better future.
 

The Book - The Changemaker Attitude


The book is written in 3 Parts....

Part 1 contains the introduction + 3 additional chapters. This section examines the scope of the environmental issue and how many of us have become disheartened as well as why individual changemakers matter. 

Part 2 contains Chapters 4-8. Here I will dispel myths about needing certain experiences and advantages to create meaningful change. I will also introduce characters like Hugh and Ahmed, creators of the Evocco app which allows consumers to understand the impacts of their food choices. 

Part 3 contains Chapters 9-15. In these chapters I will discuss some of the lessons I have learned that contribute to the changemaker attitude such as using your voice in a productive manner without adding to the noise and how to fake it til you make it. 
 

What I Need & What You'll Get


This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in July 2020
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this summer

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.


I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish

  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

About the Author

Jordan Fox is a sophomore at the University of Pennsylvania studying International Relations and Engineering Entrepreneurship. 

I wrote this book because I saw how paralyzing the overwhelming climate change news was to everyone, even those who care deeply about the subject and want to know if there are other ways to attack the problem. 

Outside of writing this book I can be found skiing or hiking in my home state of Colorado, and traveling as much as humanly possible. 

For more information you can connect with Jordan at jordanf3@sas.upenn.edu and Twitter @Jordan_Fox3.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
  • Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #ChangemakerAttitude and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page
  • Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media. 

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Jordan Fox

story:
About Piggy And Plants

Piggy and Plants is the story of a small pig called Piggy, his best friend (a mysterious duck called Kak), plants, and snacks. Piggy is a contemplative pig who finds inspiration in the mundane, and the nurturing of plant life through the seasons.

The concept arose as we found that even in the face of personal sorrow and public upheaval, it is possible to find comfort and value in simple pastimes such as plant-watering and  porch-sitting. We wanted to channel these small comforts and share them. Piggy and Plants is a tranquil and whimsical book—a respite from the daily grind and tumult.

 

Artwork+Writing

We decided to portray Piggy at home throughout the seasons—the story centers on Piggy’s daily life, which is quietly thrilling—He watches a flower bloom at night, finds a giant edible mushroom, gets snowed in with Kak, and many other adventures. The writing style is expressive and atmospheric, but comprehensible, so that it might be enjoyed by very young readers as well as older readers.

Each page of Piggy and Plants is an original oil painting.  By carefully choosing each color palate and composition, we captured the snug atmosphere of Piggy’s home and garden as he putters around and philosophizes over his plants through the seasons. Each illustration is playful and evocative, and can be appreciated both as an individual artwork and as part of the story of Piggy and Plants.

Follow the progress of Piggy and Plants here.

About Fundraising

Printing locally is expensive, but worth it. We want to work together with local NJ printers G&H Soho to produce a book that is reflective of the labor and care put into each page. With every 8x10 inch page in full-color, and in softcover format, Piggy and Plants costs $3.5 per book to produce. That means that a print run of only 1000 copies could cost over $3000. Any contribution you can make is appreciated, including sharing our campaign with your pals!

 

About The Authors

We met randomly in Jersey City in 2013. That meeting started with a conversation about art, and that conversation has continued over the past four years, manifesting as over ten co-curated exhibitions, five public murals, a co-owned business, and now in Piggy and Plants. As with our other projects, Piggy and Plants is the product of our best abilities combined—Allison’s writing and organization, and Sam’s painting and design.

 

Allison Remy Hall

I believe that what we read as children has the potential to be intellectually, spiritually, and aesthetically formative far into adulthood. Some of my favorite children’s books and abiding influences are Tove Janson’s Moomin series, L.M. Boston’s Green Knowe series, and Robert McCloskey’s Time Of Wonder. Someday I’d like to live somewhere with enough backyard to have a small pig, and a whole lot of plants.

 

Sam Pullin

I will always be a fan of Ron Van Der Meer’s Monster Island, William Steig’s Doctor De Soto, and Where The Wild Things are, by Maurice Sendak. The books that were read to me when I was a child stimulated my imagination, and continue to influence my artwork both thematically and aesthetically. Someday I'd like to travel the world making artwork with a pig and a cat as assistants.

This campaign aims to raise funds to cover the remaining expenses for producing and printing a new (the fifth) issue of Cairobserver.com.

This issue will be launched on 18 October at Rawabet Theater/Townhouse Gallery in downtown Cairo.

The #UNIVERSITY issue is co-edited with Shaimaa Ashour and is designed by Ahmad Hammoud.

Cairobserver is the start of a conversation about Cairo’s architecture and buildings, urban fabric and city life. The site was founded in 2011, the first print issue was released in May 2012.

The site has released four magazine issues, you can view them and download pdfs here: http://cairobserver.com/print

Cairobserver's wide audience is reflected by the variety of media outlets that have featured the project in the last year, including Ahram Online, the Guardian, the Middle East Research and Information Project and Brownbook.


The print magazines are entirely self funded. This is a DIY publishing project with content sourced from the community. It functions as an alternative publishing effort to stimulate debate and discourse around issues pertaining to the city. Magazine issues (around 50 pages) are printed in a run of 2000 copies, which are distributed for free during launch events and at select pick up points, mostly in downtown Cairo.

The expenses of making the magazine are in its design, translation of texts (most articles are sent in English and are translated into Arabic), and printing.

The new issue's focus on universities brings together articles on topics such as the history of university education in Egypt, architectural education, campus architecture, campus life, as well as profiles of notable individuals at Cairo University's school of architecture and special topics such as the image of the American University in Cairo in Arab literature. Contributors include Samia Mehrez, Emad Abou Ghazi, Khaled El Khamissi, Hoda Sadda, Farida Makar, Amr Abdel Kawi and many more including young scholars and students.

Cairobserver is an online platform that acts as a focal point of architectural and urban discourse in Egypt. The blog provides a space for writings by specialists and non-specialists, students and teachers, city residents and visitors, architects and concerned citizens. The aim is to stimulate public debate and conversation about the architecture, urbanism and cultural heritage of Cairo, other Egyptian cities and beyond.

Cairobserver is dedicated to presenting visitors and residents with lucid analysis, commentary and information about Cairo’s architecture and urbanism. A major aim of the project is to confront stereotypical views of Cairo by enriching the ways in which professionals, students and residents understand the policies that shape the city. The site also explores Cairo’s history and sites, its urban and architectural merits and the city’s many challenges. Additionally, Cairobserver aims to connect readers with the activism and grassroots action that engage with Cairo’s urban reality.

story:
For more detailed information on my project and to read portions of my in-process manuscript, please visit my writing page, Nothing Is Ever Done When Someone Dies In Mexico.

As I walked into the 2013 Association of Writers & Writing Programs Conference (AWP), I was still working toward my MFA in Creative Writing.  I classified myself as an inexperienced writer and found myself thoroughly intimidated (and in awe) of the numerous other authors surrounding me.  Lecture after lecture, I questioned whether or not I would ever find a worthy inspiration for writing, as well as the confidence to lump myself into this community of accomplished writers.

While in Boston, it was during one particular, unexpected workshop that I found a spark of interest.  After abandoning my first choice lecture, I wandered into Epistolophilia: Using Letters and Diaries in Creative Writing.  Julija Sukys, and her fellow panel members, spoke on how found writings such as letters and journals could easily be used to create an amazing text. My brain began spinning wildly with all the possibilities!

Upon my return to Colorado, I stumbled across my paternal grandmother's journal, documenting nearly 40 years of her life as an abused youth, Mexican immigrant, and broken wife.  Originally drafted in Spanish, my father and aunt kindly offered a translated version. I sat down and began the process of channeling a woman I barely knew. Words began to flow and I found myself writing. 

Several months ago, I stepped out on a limb and submitted a portion of this growing text to a contest.  Up until that point, I talked myself out of previous contest opportunities over a fear of rejection - I am not a fan of someone telling me that my writing was trite and meaningless. I could not handle that instance of realization that I might not meet the "Writer Job Description."  However, something made me want to submit. Although money was tight (currently a one-income household), I took the chance and submitted.  Imagine my hysterical fit of surprise and excitement after being notified that I was the poetry category winner of the 2014 San Miguel Writers' Conference Writing Contest.  I was awarded entrance to the conference, free of charge, as well as housing.  I have been floating on Cloud Nine ever since.

2014 San Miguel Writers Conference Writing Contest Winners

So here's the part where you, the generous donor and supporter come in...

This conference is offered in the birthplace of my paternal grandmother, Maria Cabrera.  My Grandma Cita, as we lovingly nicknamed her, left this place many, many, many years ago.  She passed away when I was just a toddler, so to receive an opportunity to connect with her beyond simply her writing is truly a blessing!  Although I was awarded a conference package and housing, other expenses are making it difficult to attend.  I will need to pay for airfare and shuttle rides and some meals.  In addition, the conference package does not include the final day of lectures and workshops - I would also love to attend those as well...

San Miguel Writers Conference 2014

This experience has additional "once in a lifetime" opportunities as well...

  • Authors such as Yann Martel (Life Of Pi) and Laura Esquivel (Like Water For Chocolate) will be present.
  • Contest winning authors are given an opportunity to headline an evening of readings.
  • Contest winners are given two pitch sessions with successful Literary Agents.

I truly want this opportunity to showcase my writing, as well as secure representation and possible publication.  I have chosen to meet with literary agents:

- Andy Ross

-Jeff Kleinman

I've come too far now and I need to see this through. I want to walk down the halls of my next AWP conference knowing I've earned my right to call myself a writer.

Please take time to look through my project page:

Nothing Is Ever Done When Someone Dies In Mexico

Your donation will be deeply appreciated. For those who cannot help, simply spread the word! Share this campaign link on social media and email.  Get the word out!

Thank you and Cheers!!!

story:
Story of My Book

Love is Bananas: Looking for Love in all the Wrong Places (working title) 

Love is Bananas: Looking for Love in All the Wrong Places. This book is about love. The confusing, gooey, odd, hard, magical, and bizarre things that have to do with love. It’s the one thing everybody wants. A business coach asked me a question seven years ago when I was at the lowest point in my life:

What is your definition of love? 

It rocked my world and opened my eyes about why I was in a rut. Since then I have asked three questions to hundreds of people around the world: 

1. What is your definition of love?
2. How many times have you been in love?
3. Do you love yourself? 

From a dirty motel room in Nashville, Tennessee to a rusty taxi in Somala, I have traveled the world asking those three questions and what I found was painstakingly simple: Love is easy. 

I have searched the world and uncovered the truth. I can’t wait until you discover it for yourself in these stories. 

My name is Trey Humphreys, and I am the author of Love is Bananas: Looking for Love in All the Wrong Places. I wrote this book because I have struggled to learn about love and want it to be uncomplicated for you. Self love, romantic love, and love for life. I used to hate myself and always ran from intimate relationships. A disaster of a human being full of self-loathing, fear of commitment, hiding behind masks, and never believing in myself. I set out to change it, and this book is what I found. What I have learned on this wild journey about love has transformed my life and feelings about love...finally. 

I have asked the same three questions to crackheads, centurions, religious leaders, and taxi drivers all over the world: 

What is your definition of love?

How many times have you been in love?

Do you love yourself? 

I hope that, in reading this book, you discover that love is simple. It is right in front of you if you open your eyes and heart. Oh, that is good stuff! I should write a book. Good news...I did it.

In this book, you will learn how to love through narratives like:

  • Elizabeth, the 24-year-old homeless girl with HIV and cancer who I met in a dirty motel. We drank straight vodka as she told me her story. She never shed a tear until I asked if she loved herself. She did not, and my question broke her.
  • My Yemeni guide who told me his love story as we drove through the desert in the back of a Toyota truck. He fell in love with a Canadian girl when he was 18 and planned to move to Canada and start a life with her. His father found out, burned his passport, and arranged his marriage. Now he is fighting to get his family out of Yemen. 
  • Lester, the greatest best friend in the history of the world, who drove four hours to visit his buddy in prison, every week, for 30 years. 

Love is Bananas speaks to those who are lost and looking, wild-eyed and wandering, and huge-hearted, but overthinking. Let’s grapple with love. Let’s learn that a life we fucking love is right in front of us. People to love are right in front of us. Let’s quit eating pizza alone on Friday nights and light our lives on fire. 

This book is for people who have been on 14 dating apps for the last five years or get anxiety looking in the mirror. This book is for people who spend more money on self-help books than dinners with friends. This book is for the purposeless, hopelessly romantic, and therapeutically exhausted. Hell, it’s for folks who just need to laugh. God knows laughter might just cure everything.

Ultimately, I hope that this book forces you to open your eyes and see that love is all around us. I also want people to get drunk on wine and debate these three questions with me: 

           What is the definition of love? 

How do you fall in love? 

How do you love yourself? 

I look forward to laughing, crying, and empowering readers to become experts at love. Love is easy, and I prove it in this book. You will be the master of love, or I will sue myself. 

The Book 

I wrote the book in three parts because three is my lucky number AND the magical number of the universe.

To see how your story can be a part of my book, click on my EPIC HERO perk!

And more...

About the Author

I am a serial entrepreneur who has traveled to the most dangerous countries in the world and am obsessed with one thing: getting people unstuck. I was a professional mascot, turned nightclub DJ, and dive bar owner who has been to 35 crazy countries in the past two years looking for love in all the wrong places. I won the College Mascot National Championship, got attacked by three chimpanzees in Zambia, and started a party bus company called the Fur Bus. 

I am on an adventure right now to live in Airbnbs around the world as I design and execute programs to get people unstuck, connect, and dream far bigger than they every imagined. I have stepped foot in Libya, Yemen, Somalia, and the South of France studying human behavior and exploring parts unknown to capture lessons on life and love. I believe in creating a life you love and stepping right into it. I also believe in Love. 

I wrote this book because love and I have battled my entire life. A single question from a business coach eight years ago changed my life forever. He asked me, "What is your definition of love?" My answer was horrific. And thus, I embarked on a mission to course correct. I have always struggled to give and accept love and hope the stories in this book will help us both realize that love is not only bananas but also easy. 

For more information you can connect with me at humphreys.trey@gmail.com and @treygoesglobal on all social platforms. Let’s be friends.

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each preorder tier. Like the gold pot at the end of the rainbow. 

The risk of delivering the presale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will work closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all presale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you ordered are scheduled to ship. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please share my Presale Campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family, and network. Please use #treygoesglobal and tag me and my publisher, New Degree Press, so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • Share my Presale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page.
  • Please share my book with five friends, family members, or co-workers you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support! I love you. Mean it. 

Love and more love,
Trey
